criteria: Understanding the relationship between rational exponents and radicals.
Applying the properties of integer exponents to rational exponents.
Converting between radical and rational exponent notation.
descriptions: Student does not demonstrate an understanding of rational exponents or radicals.
Student can identify rational exponents and radicals but cannot explain the relationship between them.
Student can partially explain how rational exponents relate to radicals but struggles with the underlying principles.
Student can explain how rational exponents relate to radicals using properties of exponents but may lack clarity or precision.
Student clearly explains and demonstrates the relationship between rational exponents and radicals, using exponent properties effectively.

Student provides a comprehensive and insightful explanation of the relationship between rational exponents and radicals, including justifications based on exponent properties and providing clear examples.
Student does not apply the properties of integer exponents to rational exponents.
Student attempts to apply the properties of integer exponents to rational exponents but makes significant errors.
Student applies some properties of integer exponents to rational exponents but demonstrates inconsistencies or misunderstanding.
Student applies properties of integer exponents to rational exponents correctly in basic cases, but struggles with more complex problems.
Student consistently applies properties of integer exponents to rational exponents accurately and efficiently.
Student demonstrates mastery in applying properties of integer exponents to rational exponents, including complex and non-standard problems, and can explain the reasoning behind each step.
Student cannot convert between radical and rational exponent notation.
Student attempts to convert between radical and rational exponent notation but makes frequent errors.
Student can convert between radical and rational exponent notation in simple cases but struggles with more complex expressions.
Student converts between radical and rational exponent notation with reasonable accuracy, but may require some guidance.
Student accurately and efficiently converts between radical and rational exponent notation.
Student demonstrates fluency in converting between radical and rational exponent notation, including complex and unconventional expressions, and can justify the equivalence of different notations.
